content:
78 year-old lady referred for SABR assessment

Diagnosis:
T1bN0M0 squamous cell carcinoma left lower lobe. PD-L1 <1%

Proposed treatment:
Stereotactic ablative body radiotherapy (55Gy in 5 fractions)

PET-CT 15.03.25: 18mm LLL peripheral nodule, SUV 8.2
PFTs: FEV1 1.9L (85%), TLCO 72%
CT guided biopsy confirmed moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma

Past Medical History:
Paroxysmal AF on anticoagulation
COPD with previous exacerbation 2023
Osteoarthritis both knees
No previous thoracic radiotherapy
No pacemaker/defibrillator

Drug History:
Edoxaban 60mg od
Fluticasone/vilanterol inhaler
Pantoprazole 40mg od
Paracetamol prn
Allergy to penicillin (rash)

Social history:
Lives with husband
Mobility limited by arthritis
Ex-smoker 40 pack years, stopped 2015
Minimal alcohol
Retired postal worker

Current status:
Mobile with walking stick
Exercise tolerance 100m on flat
Mild occasional cough
No haemoptysis
Weight stable

Examination:
PS 1-2
Mild wheeze right base
Regular rhythm
No peripheral edema

Discussion:
Explained diagnosis of early stage lung cancer
Outlined role of SABR with curative intent
Detailed discussion of procedure, immobilization requirements, and potential side effects including fatigue, chest wall pain, and small risk of radiation pneumonitis
Patient demonstrates good understanding and wishes to proceed
Consent obtained

Plan:
To proceed with SABR 55Gy in 5 fractions
Booking for planning CT next week
Provided emergency contact details
Follow-up arranged for 3 months post treatment

cancer_timeline.value: PET-CT shows 18mm LLL peripheral nodule, SUV 8.2
CT guided biopsy confirmed moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma

status_updates.value: Early stage left lower lobe lung cancer suitable for curative SABR, presenting with good performance status despite comorbidities including COPD and AF
To proceed with SABR 55Gy in 5 fractions
Booking for planning CT next week
Follow-up arranged for 3 months post treatment
